Posted By: iantewks (4/20/2010 6:38:08 PM)

posts.post_content:
Using the Geometric distribution, we can approximate the number of cards Treasure Hunt will draw. Assuming a sixty card deck, then the approximate expected value of the number of cards you will draw is 1/p, where p is the probability that you stop drawing, or about 1 - (# of lands)/60. While this isn't exactly the true expected value, it's close enough to make a decision.  
  
Lands / Expected # of cards  
22 / 1.58  
23 / 1.62  
24 / 1.67  
25 / 1.71  
26 / 1.76  
27 / 1.82  
  
Is ![1](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=1&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol) too much to draw between 1 and 2 cards most of the time? I'll have to go with [Ponder](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ponder) on this one.

posts.post_content:
i haven't seen anyone mention it, so i'll throw it out there. This + stuff to play additional lands (such as [walking atlas](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=walking atlas)) + the animate lands could make for a really interesting deck. With only a few non-land cards in your deck, you could blow up your opponent pretty quickly with just lands.  
  
[Celestial Colonnade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Celestial Colonnade)  
[Creeping Tar Pit](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Creeping Tar Pit)  
[Lavaclaw reaches](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lavaclaw reaches)  
[Raging Ravine](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Raging Ravine)  
[Stirring wildwood](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stirring wildwood)  
  
Probably won't make tournament quality with this, but it'd be a really fun casual deck

posts.post_content: You need a way to manipulate the top cards of your library; otherwise it's too risky, and you may end up spending 2 mana to draw 1 card. However, with stuff like jace's brainstorm (or even his +2 ability), the new blue land that lets you rearrange 3 cards, it can easily turn 2 mana into a 3-4+ card draw.

Posted By: Dark_Raider (11/11/2010 1:30:24 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Divination draws you 2 cards for 3 mana. On average this draws you something like 1.75 cards for 2 mana. It's already better than Divination. Then you have halimar depths, which basically turns treasure hunt into a guaranteed divination, always, and quite often a sorcery-speed ancestral recall for one more mana. Then you have Jace, The Mind Sculptor, who basically turns this into drawing 3,4, 5 cards? It turns Jace's brainstorm into ancestral recall. Brainstorm is already the best card in legacy! Even if you have nothing to do with your surplus land, you are still drawing through dead cards you would have had to draw anyway, making Jace's next brainstorm even more superpowered. Really amazing. 5/5, all the way.
posts.html:

Really amazing. 5/5, all the way.

posts.post_content:
The interesting thing about this, to me, is not exactly the number of cards drawn. It's the quality. In the early game, you can play this to grab up to N lands, where N is the number of lands left in your deck. This will, of course, help you hit your land drops as well as thin your deck. In the late game, you can play this to draw cards without the risk of drawing into nothing but land.  
  
FunkyMo109's \*\*\*ysis shows us that it's not the best card draw spell in terms of raw quantity of cards under normal cir\*\*\*stances, but it always draws exactly one nonland card. I can see myself using it.
posts.html:

In the late game, you can play this to draw cards without the risk of drawing into nothing but land.
